author: iSazonov

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
@SteveL-MSFT CI OSX failed in Start-Sleep.Tests.ps1 - should we fix the test?
```
Description: Should work properly when sleeping with Milliseconds
Name:        Start-Sleep DRT Unit Tests.Should work properly when sleeping with Milliseconds
message:
Expected {1051} to be less than {1050}
stack-trace:
at line: 20 in /Users/travis/build/PowerShell/PowerShell/test/powershell/Modules/Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility/Start-Sleep.Tests.ps1
$watch.ElapsedMilliseconds | Should BeLessThan 1050
```

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @iSazonov already have a PR for start-sleep tests https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/4049

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Should we repair .nuget\packages folder in an user profile folder?

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: @iSazonov I'm not sure I understand what you are suggesting. Can you please elaborate?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: In my  .nuget\packages folder I see packages of multiple versions. I'm afraid that this can lead to side effects, especially when we are restoring a previous dotnet version.

comments.author: daxian-dbw
comments.body: It's fine. dotnet-cli is designed to work side by side, and it's totally legitimate to have different projects built against different versions of .NET Core.

title: Check a dotnet version in Start-PSBuild
